Comments_List: I gained an understanding of differential equations, linear algebra, complex analysis, vector calculus, and Laplace/Fourier tansforms.
I learned many commonly used mathematical techniques to solve problems in science and engineering.
enginering math. Solving ODE, PDE. Learn a lot about complex function
nothing. just some basic math skills.
Reviewed multivariable calculus and Diff EQs
math skills for engineering
This course taught core necessary mathematical skills I will use going forward in my research
Basic engineering mathematics skills
I learned basic tools/approaches for solving a variety of problems using differential equations, linear algebra, complex analysis, etc.
Vectors, differential calculus, linear algebra, Fourier and Laplace transforms
The strength is that this class covers a wide range of topics. One thing I wish is that the practice problems we do in class could be harder.
learning a lot of math knowledge that can help me  to understand the equation in advanced chemistry.
strength is that it focuses on only basic math skills
I think it's pretty strong actually.  Not my subject of choice, but it gets the point across.
very systematic, very well-delivered
Strengths are that It was very comprehensive, weaknesses are that it could have been more applied

Strength: covers many important topics
Weakness: too much memorization and not much emphasis on problem solving skills

A strength is that the course focuses on techniques to solve general classes of problem, thereby giving us a toolbox of approaches. However, the course is rather proof-driven for an engineering course - it would benefit from more application of the math we were learning.
It is what it is

The class is well-organized and most of the topics is potentially useful for our research. It would be better to add more cases where these analysis method s are used in actually research or applications.
n/a: Course is a requirement for all engineering grad students.
Yes this class covers a wide range of commonly used mathematical techniques in solving problems in engineering and science.
Yes. Professor Paul Van Tassel is a good teacher. His class is clear.
maybe only if they want a chilled out math course
Only take it if you like doing hard core mathematics.  There is a statistics alternative for engineering grads here that allows you to bypass doing rigorous math problem sets if that's not your jam.
yes
I would recommend this course to a student who does not have the background outlined in the textbook used for this course. The mathematical skills are necessary for research
Yes, if their mathematics background is lacking
Yes, if you want to learn some basic concepts in multiple different mathematical disciplines. Not exactly a good engineering math class though, in that it is very proof-heavy.
Yes, intense but good
